text: The prologue music!!  Once upon a time, in a faraway land,  A young Prince lived in a shining castle.  Although he had everything his heart desired,  The Prince was spoiled, selfish, and unkind.  But then, one winter's night,  An old beggar woman came to the castle  And offered him a single rose In return for shelter from the bitter cold.  Repulsed by her haggard appearance,  The Prince sneered at the gift,  And turned the old woman away.  But she warned him not to be deceived by appearances,  For Beauty is found within.  And when he dismissed her again,  The old woman's ugliness melted away  To reveal a beautiful Enchantress.  The Prince tried to apologize, but it was too late,  For she had seen that there was no love in his heart.  And as punishment,  She transformed him into a hideous beast,  And placed a powerful spell on the castle,  And all who lived there.  Ashamed of his monstrous form,  The beast concealed himself inside his castle,  With a magic mirror as his only window to the outside world.  The Rose she had offered,  Was truly an enchanted rose,  Which would bloom until his twenty-first year.  If he could learn to love another,  And earn her love in return  By the time the last petal fell,  Then the spell would be broken. If not, he would be doomed to remain a beast  For all time.  As the years passed,  He fell into despair, and lost all hope,  For who could ever learn to love... a Beast?
author: Christian Yancey

text: Once upon a time in a faraway land, a young prince lived in a shining castle. Although he had everything his heart desired, the prince was spoiled, selfish, and unkind. But then, one winter's night, an old beggar woman came to the castle and offered him a single rose in return for shelter from the bitter cold. Repulsed by her haggard appearance, the prince sneered at the gift and turned the old woman away, but she warned him not to be deceived by appearances, for beauty is found within. And when he dismissed her again, the old woman's ugliness melted away to reveal a beautiful enchantress. The prince tried to apologize, but it was too late, for she had seen that there was no love in his heart. And as punishment, she transformed him into a hideous beast and placed a powerful spell on the castle and all who lived there.  Ashamed of his monstrous form, the beast concealed himself inside his castle, with a magic mirror as his only window to the outside world. The rose she had offered was truly an enchanted rose which would bloom until his 21st year. If he could learn to love another and earn her love in return by the time the last petal fell, then the spell would be broken. If not, he would be doomed to remain a beast for all time. As the years passed, he fell into despair and lost all hope for who could ever learn to love a beast?

Â Its cool to see the Beastâ€™s castle transcend from pleasant and beautiful castle to a place that is dark and somewhat eerie. As for Emma Watson as Belle, despite you can see only a tiny glimpse of her at the end of the trailer you can already tell that she fits the character perfectly and you can see it in her eyes. I know that she is going to an amazing job bringing one of my favourite Disney Princesses to life. text: Beauty & the Beast is such an hypocrite story with a phony message. It is supposed to be about a beautiful woman who eventually looks past the appearance of a man and falls in love with him, right ? In truth, it completely and intentionnaly occults the fact that "the beast" is tall and strong, which is at least equally attractive for any woman than a pretty face. Just go out and see how many beautiful woman are in couple with tall ugly guys. And this story perpetuates this by basically sending the message "It's OK if a man is not pretty as long as he is tall, strong and can protect you".   I would be very curious to see if Belle eventually falls in love with "the beast" if he was a small, weak creature.

text: "What if she is the oooooone?" OMG.. worst line-reading in faux french ever. According to IMDB, Ewan McGregor is supposed to be Lumiere, a candlestick that impersonates  Maurice Chevalier, and he really doesn't. I thought Ian McKellen's voice was the perfect Lumiere until I read that he plays Cogsworth! Ewan must have been cast as Lumiere only because he can sing, overlooking the fact that he cannot keep a french accent or sound anything like the original character which is sad. Sorry for the rant, it really just irked me that they screwed up Lumiere, he's my fave character so naturally I'm disappointed. The rest of this looks beautiful so far, and with how well they've done the "Alice" films, I cannot wait to see the CGI Beast!

text: Why are they doing this. The original was perfect and the best Disney movie that I have ever seen. The characters were well thought out, the beast looked like an actual beast and the villain was well developed. The time it took to have the characters fall in love was great, since they didn't just meet and fall in love instantly. The songs were great, the art was great, and even the side characters were great. The suspense, the drama, the happiness, the tear jerks were planed out well. The only thing bad was the way the beast looked as human. Maybe they could have kept him the beast at the end or not but the only reason why I have that one nit pit was because we fell in love with the beast and not the human. Besides that it was an amazing movie. The fact that they are remaking their very best film (aside from Toy Story) is that they have run out of ideas. Disney I hate to say it since I love you but, Just stop, please just stop. These remakes aren't helping you in any way. Come up with some new original ideas for shows and movies. The shows are good(except Gravity Falls with is awesome) but the movies are just turning into stereotypes after stereotypes, with bland character/actors, and remakes that make the remake worse, not better .  So please Disney stop with the remakes and come up with more original ideas. Please.

text: A few concerns. One, the cast is all British, yet the setting is in France. Two, Disney's most recent live action remakes have ranged from decent (Cinderella, The Jungle Book) to god awful (Alice in Wonderland, Maleficent). Three, Ewan McGregor sounds terrible as Lumiere! Seriously, who thought that this was a good idea?  That being said, this trailer looks incredible! Beauty and the Beast is still my favorite Disney animated movie (though Hunchback is a close second). The movie is flawless and gorgeously animated! As soon as that Alan Menken score kicked in, I was immediately transported back to that same feeling of Disney magic that the original film gave me back in 1997 when I first saw it. The castle itself is just dripping in atmosphere and Emma Watson looks like she'll make a great Belle! Here's to hoping that this movie can fulfill our unrealistic expectations!

text: Hereâ€™s your first look at Beauty and the Beast, a live-action retelling of the Disney classicğŸŒ¹Coming to theatres 3.17.17. #BeOurGuest  Disneyâ€™s â€œBeauty and the Beastâ€ is a live-action re-telling of the studioâ€™s animated classic which refashions the classic characters from the tale as old as time for a contemporary audience, staying true to the original music while updating the score with several new songs. â€œBeauty and the Beastâ€ is the fantastic journey of Belle, a bright, beautiful and independent young woman who is taken prisoner by a beast in his castle. Despite her fears, she befriends the castleâ€™s enchanted staff and learns to look beyond the Beastâ€™s hideous exterior and realize the kind heart and soul of the true Prince within. The film stars: Emma Watson as Belle; Dan Stevens as the Beast; Luke Evans as Gaston, the handsome, but shallow villager who woos Belle; OscarÂ® winner Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belleâ€™s eccentric, but lovable father; Josh Gad as Lefou, Gastonâ€™s long-suffering aide-de-camp; Golden GlobeÂ® nominee Ewan McGregor as Lumiere, the candelabra; Oscar nominee Stanley Tucci as Maestro Cadenza, the harpsichord; Gugu Mbatha-Raw as Plumette, the feather duster; six-time Tony AwardÂ® winner Audra McDonald as Madame Garderobe, the wardrobe; Oscar nominee Ian McKellen as Cogsworth, the mantel clock; and two-time Academy AwardÂ® winner Emma Thompson as the teapot, Mrs. Potts.  Directed by OscarÂ® winner Bill Condon from a screenplay by TBD based on the 1991 animated film, the film is produced by Mandeville Filmsâ€™ David Hoberman and Todd Lieberman with eight-time Oscar-winning composer Alan Menken, who won two Academy AwardsÂ® (Best Original Score and Best Song) for the 1991 animated film, providing the score, which will include new recordings of the original songs written by Menken and Howard Ashman, as well as several new songs written by Menken and three-time Oscar winner Tim Rice. â€œBeauty and the Beastâ€ will be released in U.S. theaters on March 17, 2017.

text: I love the look and feel of this trailer. BATB is my favorite Disney moive of all time, and this trailer hits the nostalgia hard. I'm really glad they seem to be staying true to the original story rather than reimagining it too much. However, I just can't get behind Emma Watson as Belle. In the original animated move, Belle was such a strong female character, and I just don't get that same feeling of strength from Emma Watson. Her voice is too mousy and her body frame is too small. Anne Hathaway would have been perfect for this role 5 or 10 years ago, but she's probably too old now. Oh well. Hopefully Emma Watson will be able to pull it off, but I have serious doubts.

text: Judging from the look of the castle and DAT CAST, this will very possibly/probably be my favorite live-action fairy tale telling. So excited to see all the characters. I'm sure I won't be able to stop thinking of the perfect-beyond-perfect animated voices and designs, but for some reason I'm feeling strong positive vibes about this one, and expect these to be awesome as well. Especially excited to see the ones who are new or different from the animated versions we know (e.g., Maestro Cadenza or Plumette--since the feather duster we saw in the classic was called Babette...but I'm sure they've got more than one maid/duster in that place, lol.) text: If thereÂ´s a scene of this movie that I crave to watch is "Gaston". Think about it: Luke Evans swallowing 4 raw eggs whole, showing off his carpet of virility, snapping a belt with one single bite and punching Josh Gad across a room as if he were a ragdoll, ragequitting after losing a chess match. And letÂ´s not forget the "crazy old Maurice" bit. I hope the director will turn this scene into a moment of pure hilarity for both children and adults ("Every last INCH *blink* of him is covered with hair"...Youtube Poops memories...Josh Gad being awfully beaten by everybody...Maurice being flung out of the door because Gaston would have helped him *out* later!).    Seriously, their characters have a lot of potential. After all, Gaston is supposed to be the monster opposed to the more human-like Beast.

text: So many people be hatin' on Emma Watson because they don't like the way she looks, haha....beauty is in the eye of the beholder. Are we all forgetting the whole POINT of the story? The whole don't judge a book by its cover thing. Belle fell in love with the Beast despite the fact that he was this ugly monstrous thing, because she saw past all that. His character and his heart made him beautiful to Belle and that's why she loved him. So many people here are getting caught up on the way someone looks. Maybe Disney's timing on this right...we all need a refresher on the definition of "true beauty." ;)

text: Okay, besides all the "feminazi Emma Watson" comments, the description says that Belle was "taken prisoner." There are also a lot of theories that Belle has Stockholm Syndrome and that's the only reason she fell in love with the beast or how the beast was abusive towards Belle and he made her his slave. All of that being completely false because Belle wanted to be held prisoner to save her father and even when she took his place she was never treated wrongly. Sure the beast had some outbursts and anger issues but he never actually hurt Belle. She was never "taken prisoner" and she was able to leave the castle whenever she wanted. This rant was rather irrelevant but reading something like "Belle was a prisoner" just pisses me off because it isn't true.

text: Yet another Disney Live Action Reboot, or "Deboot" as I call them. Of course they don't show us any of the other characters besides Belle, because they're gonna be extremely fake CGI. Like Cinderella, the old one will always be better, and the new one will be complete shit with half-assed acting, characters that act OOC from their animated counterparts, and last but not least: unsubtle morals!  If you want a good Disney reboot, watch Jungle Book 2016. It stays true to the original story and movie, and aren't utter bullcrap like the other Fairy Tales Disney is giving a makeover.

text: If it is true that the Disney version of Beauty and the Beast is about an abusive relationship, how in the actual hell is this movie getting made!? Feminists the world over were and/or are going to throw a Twitter s**tstorm about how this is yet another glorified case of domestic abuse, that does nothing but reinforce Patriarchy and straight, white male oppression over "poor, helpless" women.   I mean, the fact that self-professed feminist Emma Watson appears to be playing Belle [the victim] and is okay with that--since she took on the role--should strike everyone as odd, considering her stance on feminism. Or maybe, because it's Disney, it gets a pass. Regardless, let's see how this transpires. Will feminists go apeshit over this movie and Watson for supporting it or will nostalgia win the day? We shall see...

author: Roshan Paul

text: What a perfect first teaser. Showing the castle going under the enchantment during the 10 years, while the unforgettable "Prologue" music from the original animated film plays was genius. Then, to hear Ewan McGregor and Ian Mckellan playing Lumiere and Cogsworth respectively was like stepping back in time to the first time I watched the animated classic. As it ends, with Belle gazing into the enchanted rose's bell jar with the "Beauty and the Beast" theme, I got chills. Calling it right now, this will be the live-action adaptation to a Disney classic that all those before or since will have to measure up to. Can't wait for March! :)

text: Once upon a time, in a faraway land,  A young Prince lived in a shining castle.  Although he had everything his heart desired,  The Prince was spoiled, selfish, and unkind.  But then, one winter's night,  An old beggar woman came to the castle  And offered him a single rose In return for shelter from the bitter cold.  Repulsed by her haggard appearance,  The Prince sneered at the gift,  And turned the old woman away.  But she warned him not to be deceived by appearances,  For Beauty is found within.  And when he dismissed her again,  The old woman's ugliness melted away  To reveal a beautiful Enchantress.  The Prince tried to apologize, but it was too late,  For she had seen that there was no love in his heart.  And as punishment,  She transformed him into a hideous beast,  And placed a powerful spell on the castle,  And all who lived there.  Ashamed of his monstrous form,  The beast concealed himself inside his castle,  With a magic mirror as his only window to the outside world.  The Rose she had offered,  Was truly an enchanted rose,  Which would bloom until his twenty-first year.  If he could learn to love another,  And earn her love in return  By the time the last petal fell,  Then the spell would be broken. If not, he would be doomed to remain a beast  For all time.  As the years passed,  He fell into despair, and lost all hope,  For who could ever learn to love... a Beast?

text: This looks cool, but why the heck are they doing this? Seriously, just why??? I can get Cinderella to some extent because the story did have problems. The side cast was super underdeveloped, it wasted too much time on the mice and stuff, and the main romance was just complete crap. I disagreed with how they changed the main character to an extent, but there was actual room for improvement there. With Beauty and the Beast, that just really isn't a thing. The story already had a great plot, solid execution, well done characters all the way around, and a really good climax. It's the type of classic where there really isn't any way to just do it better, especially in live action where the living objects and the Beast simply won't translate anywhere near as good as they do in an already animated movie. This just seems completely unnecessary and there's just no way it's going to be able to live up to the original film, so why even try instead of going out to make something original and new?  I know that sounds weird since the Disney film was based on an existing film, but I mean, come on! There's no way this is going to work as well so why is this even a thing? I mean, other than the obvious answer of "this is going to make money off of the brand recognition"...........

text: This does look good. I was impressed with the recent live-action Jungle Book and Alice in Wonderland from 2010 as far as live action remakes go. Maleficent was meh due to the fact that since her animated counterpart was so evil, making her a tragic anti-hero was disappointing. I do hope to see a live action Lion King, Hunchback and Aladdin in the near future. Also the 1996 live action 101 dalmatians is still a classic to me and they should not make another one nor a Peter Pan or Robin Hood as they have been done too much.

text: As someone pointed out, Belle is supposed to be incredibly beautiful and feminine. Emma Watson is okay-ish, more tomboyish. Her face doesn't exactly make you lick your chops. Compare to say younger versions of Angelina Jolie or Catherine Zeta-Jones or Charlize Theron or Sharon Stone.... mmm... or these days' younger generation like Jessica Alba, or Mary Elizabeth Winstead or Zoe Kravitz, or Vanessa Hudgens, or Shailene Woodley, or Elisha Cuthbert, or Merritt Patterson, or Alexandra Daddario, or Saxon Sharbino, or Crystal Reed, or Nicola Peltz... I could go on and on. Heck anyof the girls from Pretty Little Liars would do. Or if you wanna cast British how about Roxanne McKee or Gugu Mbatha-Raw or Felicity Jones... mmm... Comparing Emma Watson (in pure physical beauty) to any of the others I mention is like comparing Audrey Hepburn to Marilyn Monroe; the former a great actress and pleasant to look at no doubt but for sensual projections Norma Jean beats her hands tied behind her back

text: BEAUTY AND THE BEAST (LA BELLA Y LA BESTIA) basada en  la serie televisiva de los 70's-80's, y que se enfocaba en el deseo de protecciÃ³n de la Bestia por la heroÃ­na Belle, defendiÃ©ndola de sus perseguidores.    En la pelÃ­cula de Disney, trataba del mismo tema, en el cual la Bestia, un personaje con fisonomÃ­a atroz se escondÃ­a de sus semejantes, viviendo en la obscuridad, pero tenÃ­a sentimientos como cualquier ser viviente, que aislado por los complejos y temores propios de su fÃ­sico, huÃ­a y se escondÃ­a de la sociedad. HÃ©roe y protector de  Belle, de quien se enamorÃ³, abriÃ³ su corazÃ³n a un mundo de amor y de entendimiento; ayudÃ¡ndolo Belle a conocerse asÃ­ mismo, y darse cuenta de que el fÃ­sico NO era lo mÃ¡s importante, sino la manera de ser, que muy pocos podÃ­an conocer de Ã©l, y que solamente, La Bestia se atrevÃ­a a demostrarle a su princesa.    Una de las pelÃ­culas favoritas de los niÃ±os en la dÃ©cada de los 90's; favorita tambiÃ©n de las mamÃ¡s de aquella generaciÃ³n en la que me incluyo, que ahora nos han hecho abuelas, y que tanto disfrutamos la mayorÃ­a; y aÃºn en los desfiles de luces en las paradas de Disneyland en Anaheim, CA, Estados Unidos.   SegÃºn,  la informaciÃ³n que hemos leÃ­do en YOUTUBE.COM, esta pelÃ­cula se estrenarÃ¡ el 03/17/17.  Y de acuerdo a la informaciÃ³n que nos proveen aquÃ­, estÃ¡ basada en la misma historia de Belle, la dulce y tierna chica que personifica a la amada de La Bestia, pero con el giro que ha realizado los Estudios Disney, y adoptada para la generaciÃ³n actual.    Bien, no me importa si alguno de los actores principales de este film se ha ganado un Oscar o no.  Lo cierto es que, en lo personal no me ha gustado ninguna de las adaptaciones de las Ãºltimas pelÃ­culas de Disney, ya que los malos de la pelÃ­cula, ahora se reflejan mucho mÃ¡s malvados que antes, destruyendo la inocencia, y la candidez de nuestros pequeÃ±os.  Que mÃ¡s que gustarles, les atemoriza; y no podemos ni debemos levantar a nuestros pequeÃ±os con tantos temores, aÃºn, mÃ¡s de los que ya existen.    Si bien es cierto, que debemos educarles y enseÃ±arles a protegerse de extraÃ±os y en las diversas situaciones en las cuales puedan correr algÃºn tipo de riesgos o peligros; tambiÃ©n estamos creÃ¡ndoles mayores temores y desconfianzas, y sembrÃ¡ndoles miedos innecesarios que no les ayudan en su desarrollo mental y psicolÃ³gico.    Bien sabido es por todos los que hemos estudiado nociones de psicologÃ­a, y nos hemos cultivado en esta rama de la ciencia de la mente, que NO es correcto crear temores infundados en nuestros pequeÃ±os que le restan confianza en sÃ­ mismos, y les dificulta en sus relaciones humanas, y en el desarrollo  social. Yo, que desde niÃ±a he sido seguidora de Walt Disney, consumidora a gran escala de sus servicios y productos no he escrito este comentario como una CRÃTICA DESTRUCTIVA, sino como UNA CRÃTICA CONSTRUCTIVA por el bien de mis nietos y todos los niÃ±os y padres del mundo, que deseamos para ellos un mundo y un entorno mejor.  No critico las nuevas adaptaciones, puesto que la sociedad y su sistema es cambiante, y debemos adaptarnos a los cambios de la sociedad y las tendencias; pero, si en nuestras manos estÃ¡ mantener aquello que es la esencia humana en la balanza con mayor bondad, y conservarla, creo que serÃ­a mejor para todos.  Ya hay suficientes productoras y peliculeras que se dedican a estos tipos de pelÃ­culas, Â¿No lo creen? text: I've got a legitimate question. Why does Disney feel the need to remake all their films into a live action version? Realistically, what is it going to be except for a cash grab? We already love the original, so what's the point of a remake that will at best match it and at worse, be a movie everyone is going to regret watching? There's really no point to do remakes of these movie, the original's arguably not even that old (depending on whether a 1991 movie is considered old at this point) so really I just hope I don't see stupid live action versions of Lilo and Stitch or Aladdin or whatever. Personal rant. Carry on with buisness as usual.

text: Once upon a time, in a faraway land, a young prince lived in a shining castle. Although he had everything his heart desired, the prince was spoiled, selfish, and unkind. But then, one winter's night, an old beggar woman came to the castle and offered him a single rose in return for shelter from the bitter cold. Repulsed by her haggard appearance, the prince sneered at the gift and turned the old woman away. But she warned him not to be deceived by appearances, for beauty is found within. And when he dismissed her again, the old woman's ugliness melted away to reveal a beautiful enchantress. The prince tried to apologize, but it was too late, for she had seen that there was no love in his heart. And as punishment, she transformed him into a hideous beast and placed a powerful spell on the castle and all who lived there. Ashamed of his monstrous form, the beast concealed himself inside his castle, with a magic mirror as his only window to the outside world. The rose she had offered was truly an enchanted rose, which would bloom until his 21st year. If he could learn to love another, and earn her love in return by the time the last petal fell, then the spell would be broken. If not, he would be doomed to remain a beast for all time. As the years passed, he fell into despair and lost all hope. For who could ever learn to love a beast?

text: I wished they had chosen a French girl to play Belle. I mean one that could at least sound like Belle did in the original Disney film. I mean they did great with the Jungle Book adaptation. BUT Why did they have to choose Emma Watson? Yes, we all have known her as a bookish character from Harry Potter. But that doesn't qualify her to play Belle. I'm sorry, but she is not who I could've imagined as Belle. I mean not to body shame her but I remember Belle to have some curves. She had plump cheeks, a decent bosom and a shape throughout. I'm sorry but Emma Watson is no where near what I had in mind to play Belle. And why would they give a French character a British voice?!!??? I don't get that. Yes, for Cogsworth and the Teapot but really a British accent for Belle? Come on. I know that they're trying really hard to update everything but really?? I know there are plenty of actresses out there that could've played Belle better.

text: I full on was crying after seeing the trailer because they used the original title score. I was napping when I heard the song playing and ran to my mom and sister who showed me the trailer. I think I'm the only one of the three who recognized the score. I;m so happy they decided to use that for the first trailer. This is the best kind of trailer. They barely show any big details in order to not give things away but what they do show traps the mind and ensnares the senses.   +Space Fan Alien Robot I noticed that too! When I was telling my mom she looked so surprised! I guess she never considered it since she was distracted watching the movie with me but I always felt so bad for poor Adam. I mean, yes he was a brat, but can you honestly tell me eleven-year-olds are never brats.   Not to insult the story, though. I love Beauty and the Beast. Belle was always my favorite since I found her so relatable. And when Emma was announced to be playing Belle I was jumping around all day. My favorite actress playing my favorite Princess. I really want to hear her singing "Belle" and "Something There" I think I'm even more excited than my sister was when she found out about the live-action Cinderella movie last year.   And Lumiere! His accent was so on spot! It reminded me of watching the original movie. And Cogsworth! So many happy feeling right now!  "Be Our Guest" is going to be fantastic!  And Emma Thompson is playing Mrs. Potts! I can't wait to hear her sing "Beauty and the Beast." I'm sure she'll do a brilliant job.   So many feels with the trailer right now. I swear, the day the movie comes out I'm going to rewatch the original and then go watch it the very next day. This is going to be magical!

text: I found a leaked script online for this 2017 version of Beauty and the Beast.  *SPOILER WARNING*   Belle turns out to be a lesbian and her father doesn't approve. Her father battles with this discovery throughout the movie but he eventually learns that it's okay that she likes other girls and that he was wrong to be upset. The Beast also becomes frustrated that she's not attracted to him so he begins to wear make-up and pretty dresses to try and appeal to her. He later discovers that he actually enjoys dressing up as a woman and he begins his magical journey to becoming transgender.

text: Disney is really going downhill fast. Back then, the problems were sequels, but at least those took some creativity. Retelling the same story like Cinderella or Alice in Wonderland is just lazy. I feel insulted as a consumer, to be honest. I'm not going to spend my money to watch the exact same thing I did all those years ago. It's lazy, it's a money grab. The fact that they've been remaking movies this long is just painful for me. And some of the retellings, in my opinion, are much worse than the original, like Maleficent. So if this is a retelling, I'll hate it. If it's a remake, I'll hate it. If it's somehow a sequel, it's gonna have to win me over.  I'm scared for Incredibles 2.

text: Education is big for most of us and so is the cost of it. I have met many people who dream big but are held back because of limitations of time, networking, experience and money. Those limitations can be overcome and they are done so by the help of others around that person to support, encourage and donate into that person's life. Gift Nleko is one of those people. She has recently graduated college at Lamar University with a Bachelors in Psychology and wants to continue her education at Syracuse Universityâ€™s Dual Master's Program in Social Work and Marriage and Family Therapy beginning Fall 2016. Unfortunately, the funding for this is dauntingly high and a full ride through the McNair scholars program fell through because of lack of funds. Please follow the link and donate to her future passion to help families and others. text: This my favorite Disney movie. I fear this remake will be a disappointment. When I read that it will be made for "contemporary audiences", I can only begin to guess at the changes. Will the wolf attack be stricken to appease animal rights advocates? Will Belle be portrayed as a strong, independent, modern woman who has interests and career choices and who doesn't need or want a man? Will at least one character be portrayed as openly gay? Will Gaston be portrayed not just as a self centered bully, but as some sort of evil capitalist intent on destroying the environment? I will go see this movie when it comes out, but my guess is that I would have a better time watching the original on a big movie screen.
author: Don Gilleo

text: I know a lot of people are gonna be offended by this, but didn't Disney learn their lesson from the live-action Cinderella movie? I guess they did a bit, they changed it too much, and in this version they seem to be following the cartoon exactly.   But it's sad that Disney is even remaking these movie. ONLY reason they are making it is to cash in on all the 'nostalgia'. Sad that people these days don't get what original ideas are any more. Everything is based on a book, tv show, comic, etc....no new ideas. What will happen 10 years from now? Re-make of a remake?  Also when I heard Emma Watson was cast in this I was pissed. She can't act, wooden actress. And Belle is a very expressive character. Sad, that the only reason that people will see the movie is for her! Even tho she can't act. It's funny that she is in all these feminist things, yet the only reason she was cast/made famous/became successful was for a sexist reason! Her appearance. I find it funny that she preaches about stopping sexism when she herself is successful because of it.......

text: One of the things millennials won't understand was how popular the animated movie was back in the 80s. This defined our generation along with Transformers, Terminator, Ghost, Lion King, Titanic, Jurassic Park, Ghostbusters, Voltron, GI Joe and many other works. There literally was an explosion of creativity back then. Although you get your Avengers, Iron Man, Cap America, that definitive love story for millennials is yet to be made.

text: I don't know how to feel about all these live action remakes of classic Disney animated movies? On the one hand I like seeing new interpretations through different art forms but on the other hand it feels like I'm watching Disney shout, we don't have any new ideas and don't feel like taking chances. Yes new ideas are risks but with thousands of popular books and what not, why not try one or two of them? P.S I can't wait to see Don Bluth & Gary Goldman's Dragons Lair hand drawn animated movie. With hope it will rekindle America to go back to hand drawn animation again. I miss them as do millions around the world.

text: A tale as old as time, a legendary piece of our childhoods so timeless that we don't need the the title displayed to instantly realize what we are seeing :)  Ever since I was a little kid I have been a lifelong Disney fan & of all their animated masterpieces, my 2 all-time favorites above all others are easily Sleeping Beauty and of course Beauty & The Beast and ever since I first learned that Disney was gearing up a live-action take on arguably the greatest & most beloved & iconic of all Disney animated classics featuring a real honest to God dream cast consisting of the likes of Emma Watson, Dan Stevens, Emma Thompson, Sir Ian McKellen, Ewan McGregor, Kevin Kline, Stanley Tucci & Luke Evans not to mention the return of legendary Disney maestro Alan Menken who is scoring the live-action version just as he did the original animated legend, I have literately been counting the days until we finally get our first real glimpse at Disney's most highly anticipated movie in ages!!! God I so wish it were March'17 already!!! I'm gonna call in sick just so I can see this more than twice in the very same day come premier date!!! I hope & would love it if the original film's voice talents Paige O'Hara (Belle), Robby Benson (The Beast) & the incomparable Angela Lansbury (Mrs Potts) make cameo appearances in the live-action version, fingers crossed ;)  I cannot frickin wait :)

text: As a young boy, my favorite Disney movie was The Lion King. It was released when I was 2 and kept me entertained with it's colors and music. As I got older and  started watching horror movies and dark cult films, I realized that Beauty and the Beast was my favorite Disney film upon viewing it again at age 11 when the special edition was released on VHS. I'm really excited it's getting a live action remake and can't wait for this film.

text: Anyone who sees this is officially a sucker. It might be a great film. But what's the point? We've already got a timeless classic in beauty and the beast (1991). I commented in the jungle book (2016) trailer, saying I could understand why people went to see it (myself included) because the original was a film that released 50 years ago! And because it didn't net Disney anywhere near as much money as the original beauty and the beast did, with its initial release, VHS releases, DVD releases and bluray. The film is only 25 years old for fuck sake. This is an insult.

text: I am not convinced of Emma Watson playing Beauty, she is a good actress but the character itself that I remember isn't physically like her. I would imagine Felicity Jones as Beauty, Felicity best fits the character. And I'm not sure about beast but I imagine an actor like Jared Letto with his hairy style. I'd wanted to recognize my characters as I remember, Bella was sweet and innocent looking and " Beast " was rebellious, imposing, savage and powerful! Emma is very serious and mysterious for their own facial features and the other actor remembers me Draco Malfoy xD giving me the impression of being a pampered and spoiled child instead of rebellious one. Seriously this Beast is a fucking puppie, there's no vision in the animation team? Beast should be fucking epic,  giant, and more like a wolf instead of a lion, I don't imagine this puppie fighting against the wolf pack in the epic way "Beast" does in the cartoon movie. Anyway, I hope the performance to be excellent , as is a movie that I loved a lot in my childhood. If movie doesn't work then please make it again thinking in people who first watched the movie when it was cool even when it was oriented to children. Do something like the Jungle Book, It was amazing at the technical level

text: Let's retell the story shall we? Ahem.  "Once upon a time, in a faraway land, a young prince lived in a shining castle. Although he had everything his heart desired, the prince was spoiled, selfish, and unkind. But then, one winter's night, an old beggar woman came to the castle and offered him a single rose in return for shelter from the bitter cold. Repulsed by her haggard appearance, the prince sneered at the gift, and turned the old woman away. But she warned him not to be deceived by appearances, for beauty is found within. And when he dismissed her again, the old woman's ugliness melted away to reveal a beautiful enchantress. The prince tried to apologize, but it was too late. For she had seen that there was no love in his heart. And as punishment she transformed him into a hideous beast, and placed a powerful spell on the castle and all who lived there. Ashamed of his monstrous form, the beast concealed himself inside his castle with a magic mirror as his only window to the outside world. The rose she had offered was truly an enchanted rose, which would bloom until his twenty-first year. If he could learn to love another and earn their love in return by the time the last petal fell, then, the spell would be broken. If not, he would be doomed to remain a beast for all time. As the years passed, he fell into despair and lost all hope... for who could ever learn to love a beast?"

text: Beauty and the BeastÂ (1991)  Many scenes were storyboarded but never animated. Those include a scene where Gaston visits the asylum and a scene where the Beast is seen dragging the carcass of an animal he killed. Both where considered too gruesome for the film and the ideas were dropped. However, an animal's skeleton can be seen, though just barely since it is heavily in shadows, in the corner of the West Wing, leaving a subtle implication of just how far his transformation had effected him.  http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0101414/trivia?item=tr0790024  I wonder if they'll add these scenes in this version???

text: So let's recap on this: *Bill Condon* (_Gods and Monsters_, and _Mr. Holmes_) is going to direct it;  *Hermione* is playing Belle;  *Obi-Wan Kenobi* is playing Lumiere;  *Gandalf* is playing Cogsworth;  *Nanny McPhee* is playing Mrs. Potts;  *Otto* from _A Fish Called Wanda_ is playing Maurice (Belle's father);  *Matthew Crawley* from _Downton Abbey_ is playing the Beast; *Bard* from _The Hobbit_ films is playing Gaston; *Olaf* from _Frozen_ is playing Le Fou; and *Caesar Flickerman* is playing Cadenza;  That's a pretty stellar cast if you ask me.

text: I hope with this re-make, Disney doesn't f*** up the design/looks for the Beast. What made the Beast effective in the animated movie was he was imposing, large, threatening, scary and ferocious (like when he confronted Belle in the West Wing) and he was bad-ass, especially when he took on the wolves that were attacking Belle. But when he is mellow and during his light-hearted/comedic moments and has softened his heart towards Belle, he is cuddly and adorable just like a big teddy bear. That same effect is what Disney needs to achieve again with the Beast. I bet they will be motion-capturing the crap out of Dan Stevens who will be playing Beast/Adam. I hope they just don't slap a costume on Dan Stevens like what they did in the Broadway play. I want the Beast to look every bit as much as what he looked like in the animated movie, but since this is a live-action movie, the Beast would be photo-realistic. All Disney needs to do is look at the original beast and envision him as what/how he would look like if he existed in real life. And I hope Belle calls him by his name this time - Adam - instead of calling him "Beast". i mean, they've gotten to know each other real well during Belle's time there at his castle and then when she comes back for him, she still calls him "Beast". Lol.

text: Well just from what I can glean from a teaser trailer... It looks like theyve got the aesthetic and tone right on! The casting is fine, im sure Watson will do great. The real key to this though is character interaction between Belle and the Beast of course, but also everyone else. Nailing the humor without making it hokey. They could go really dark with this story if they want lol. Interested to see how they balance. Certain things just wont translate well to live action... And please for the love of god I hope the beast is Practical Effects!! CGI would look like shit.

text: Guys, people need to calm down. This is Beauty and the Beast we're talking about here, a tale as old as time - Disney is NOT going to stuff this up. This is an all star cast including Emma Watson, Luke Evans, Ewan McGregor and to top it off, SIR Ian McKellen - heaps of onscreen talent! Composer Alan Menken is back and as we already know, the original and fantastic soundtrack is being reused (with a few additions).  Also, after Disney's Cinderella remake which was also amazing (why are people saying otherwise? I don't know), I am anticipating more than ever Belle's yellow ballgown - that will be the determining factor as to whether this movie cuts it or not. However, I am positive Disney is well aware of the potential risk for ruining a much loved story and I am sure that this will surpass Maleficent (easily, no questions asked) and Cinderella.    In short, this is going to be amazing!! :)   Wow. I feel like  a Disney spokesperson or something

text: Dear Disney,   When I was small your films were ingenious, fun, magical and bewitching. Now that I am less small I notice your films have changed. They're all so incredibly dark and action ridden, they seriously lack humour and individuality, in fact they all appear to merge in to one ( I am not sure the orchestrated choir needs to appear in every film to signify magic ). Why the darkness? Isn't there a little bit too much darkness in the world right now? Don't our children deserve a little bit more fantasy and humour and playfulness. And lightness? That's what I used to count on Disney for. Everything doesn't have to be epic. Every actor doesn't have to be given a hand with constantly overpowering music. Let them do their job without so much help. They're getting paid pretty well. The same applies to CGI. And surely there are so many talents out there with great stories waiting to be told, without merely re-doing what has been told so well. Don't be so lazy, it should be such a joy finding new formulas. I just saw 'Alice through the Looking Glass' and couldn't have been more bored. I left the cinema feeling so incredibly disappointed and let down. But not all is bad, we still have all of your old movies to watch when humour was key and action was necessary. Plus, we still have Pixar, which although I know is now 'owned' by Disney. I see Pixar nowadays as a classier Disney. Disney to me now seems like a bunch of suits in a room. Pixar on the other hand don't seem to adhere to the belief that every scene needs music, I am not aware of them bringing in that children's choir just yet and their darkness to lightness ration seems pretty spot on! Times change I know, but there are reasons why Mary Poppins is still so popular to this day, perhaps do a little homework and work out how. Good luck with the next one.   Yours, disgruntled  UK

Like, it sounds like someone who's doing an impersonation of a French accent, rather than an actual Frenchman speaking in English (something the original actor pulled off). It's a very particular sweet spot that needs to be nailed perfectly. Otherwise, his accent is so thick that it ends up sounding really dumb. It's a shame too, because Ewan McGregor is a great actor. Let's hope it's just how it came off in the trailer, and not how it is in the actual film.

text: I'm sorry but I just saw The official trailer and I do not approve. No No this will not do. A lot of the 2004-2008 seniors will be very dissapointed. For our generations this movie enlightened us to all the turmoils of this world and the beauty of the music was so breathtaking that the movie must be breathtaking too. It has to be Emilia Clarke as Belle, a soft yet determined physique, Ewan Mcgregor as Prince Beast, and Lorant Deutsch as Lumier. I loved this movie growing up.Please do this movie right. I beg of you!

text: The film looked promising...The music, the cinematography, the atmosphere it immediately builds. Until, the voices.... Why did they make a British actor play a French candlestick's voice? And what is with Cogworth's voice???!!! Is he a mixture of Batman and Alfred's voice put together?! And then but not least Belle... Why Emma Watson?! Why her?! Just because she played a bookish character in a successful franchise doesn't mean she was Belle material. Belle doesn't  have a sarcastic tone or look. She's quiet, sweet, patient, and thoughtful of others. And very book smart. Plus Belle is a French woman!!! French women for the most part in the 17th century were quite plump. Supple hips, thighs, cheeks, and chest. Which Belle mostly had in the animated version. She wasn't drawn sultry yes, but still she had a figure. And why would they make her have a British accent?!!! It's a French Tale!!!! I know there are plenty of actresses more qualified than her.

author: Magda P

text: Emma Watson is going to own this role completely! She is like the real life version of Belle. She's got the brains and looks! Belle is a young woman, who is very clever and beautiful at the same time. Her beauty is both inside and out for the type of her person she is and how she carries herself. There's an innocence in her as well, that just makes you love her even more. Emma captures all that, because in a way that's the type of person she is in real life too. I can't wait to see her in this role. She is going to look so stunning in that famous yellow ballroom gown. Dan Stevens wasn't my first choice for the Prince/Beast, but after seeing some of his work, I think he's going to do an excellent job, plus he's "easy on the eyes" too. What you guys think of Watson and Stevens casting? If you had your pick on which other actor you love to see in these roles, who would it be?

author: Get Crusty

text: Yes, this looks like it will be good. Yes, Emma Watson is a great choice to play Belle. Yes, the castle looks amazing. But can we stop? The reason these classic Disney movies are so fantastical is they're animated. When they're turned into live-action, they become grounded. It's not a fairy tale anymore when it's made live-action; the charm the animation brought to it can't exist. That doesn't mean this won't still be a great movie, but it won't be Beaut and the Beast. I can't imagine anyone being happy if a fully CG version came out (even if you kept Emma Watson as the voice of Belle). They would say it undermines the integrity of the classic animation, and there's no point to making it CG. Well, my friends, that's the same thing with making a live-action version. Snow White, Cinderella, Peter Pan, 101 Dalmations, The Jungle Book, and now this. Keep making Disney movies, and make them live-action if you must, but can't we have some new stories?

text: Belle DOES NOT have Stockholm Syndrome! I am so sick of people writing in the comments Things like "Belle is stupid because sheÂ only fall in love because of the Stockholm Syndrome" like they wouldÂ know everything about mental illnesses or the movie. While most of the people who claim this stuff either don't know what Stockholm Syndrome really means or just didnt watch theÂ movie (or they watched it aÂ too long time ago so they simply don't remember most of the story). It could be that in other adoptations of the fairy tale the beauty really has this illness, but Disney did a really great job in not falling into this trap and made the story very believable. If you don't believe me look at the official definition of Stockholm Syndrom, it says "Stockholm SyndromeÂ is a psychological phenomenon in which hostages express empathy and sympathy and have positive feelings toward their captors ..." Alright so you might think now "but thats exactly what happened in the film", right? Then it's time for you to watch that movie again because Belle is far away from having Stockholm Syndrome! She has a really strong and independent personality and she doesn't care what society expects her to do. If she really had Stockholm Syndrom she would have fallen in love with Gaston a long time ago, because he treats her like an object or a trophy, but instead she always avoids him. And when she got imprisoned by the beast, it looked more like she hated him. Only when she flee from the castle and the beast saved her from the wolves by risking his life, she helped him as an act of compassion. After that the love story began, and not after the capturing! So stop just buying everything the internet says. This lie only went around because peopleÂ want to believe in scandals and therefore don'tÂ evenÂ verify rather it's true or not. And stop saying "It's true because I read it somewher in the internet" because that is stupid andÂ I hateÂ it so much. And please stop trying to make one ofÂ my favourite movies of all timeÂ bitter to me, thanks! (Anyway, thanks if you read this till the end and sorry for my bad english :P)

text: Beauty and the Beast (1991) is probably my all time favorite Disney  Princess film (a concept caching in on the Disney Princess and fairy  tale aspect). Not only was it nominated for Best Picture, it pretty much  made light of any other Disney film, be it Up or Toy Story 3 to be  nominated for an Oscar. At that time, that was unheard of. The story was  great, the characters were great, the songs were great and the  animation was unbelievable...  Unfortunately I am not. Because I fail to see what this film is going to  accomplish. But, that's to be said with most Disney live action remakes  nowadays, trying to, "introduce a brand new audience to Disney with  live action remakes of the original animated films". And while studies,  REALLY haven't pointed it out yet. There's a lot more I could bring up  with this movie. I'm not excited for this movie at all.   For one, making a remake of an original Disney film isn't going to win  any awards like it did last time. Second, is the music. While they are  getting the original composer Alan Menken to compose the film, sadly,  I'm not too sure how they're gonna be doing it. Also, is Celine Dion  gonna resing the song too? Third, the characters. Before I judge  anything else, I can't really blame them for getting big name actors and  actresses to play these roles. Unfortunately, I'm not really buying  Hermione as Belle when all I hear is Hermione as Belle. No offense to  Emma Watson. Fourthly is CG. I swear to Christ. Disney has a problem  with not putting enough practical effects to blend in with the amount of  CG put across it. Like for instance, make an actual model of the  castle, and not have it all CG? Prosthetic makeup for the Beast,  perhaps? (Even though I haven't seen it, I'm kinda guessing it to be CG  sadly) and a few other things.   Honestly, I really hope this film holds up, but I am kinda afraid of it  failing even though a lot of people are excited for this film, I just  thought I should get out there.
author: Scarfy Conly

Oh for those who commented earlier. Emma Watson was given voice lessons by Paige o'hara. And josh had sad in an interview "I saw a rough cut of the film and after every musical performance I wanted to stand up and applause. If you loved the original you'll love this one." I have been keep track of ALL news from this live action remake. There are COUNTLESS articles that will support what I'm saying. Please know that it's been confirmed that EACH AND EVERY actor that has been cast WILL sing!! text: Very upset. Can't Disney leave classic movies as "classics"? I haven't been too happy with the remake spree the company has gone on lately.   When I hear the iconic notes of 'Be Our Guest' or 'Belle' I think of all the vibrant colors and beautiful artwork in the original films. I don't want the CGI or the painted faces, I want the life-like cartoon style drawings!   I know I'm not the only one who feels this way. Call me ol' fashioned but there's so much at stake here remaking these classic movies that has grounded many of our childhoods in the 90's Disney Renaissance era.   Disney, I have been a fan almost since birth and I really appreciate your company. But please leave these films that gave us many great memories as kids alone. Thanks so much.
author: Adam Smith

text: From the looks of things, they're going to fix the plot hole of the first one, in which somehow already twentysomething year-old prince has to find love by his 21st birthday... Which is in 10 years,implying he was 11.... Even though he was an adult... I think they ARE actually making him 11 now when he was transformed, which could possibly mean that the enchantress gets a larger role as A villain even with Gaston's presence, since why would you curse everyone else in the castle when it was the prince who had no love? By his spoiled demeanour, I don't think he would care.    Actually that would have been cool in the first movie if the Enchantress was the villain, where it could turn out that she had a deep seeded anger and jealousy for the prince as she beloved he had no love in his heart... For HER and her alone. Then belle could come and prove beauty comes from within. The prince need to be taught humility and humanity, not just love. Or maybe I'm interpreting the story wrong.

text: Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" is my all-time favorite movie, and I was so excited to learn that Disney is remaking it in live action. I became even more excited with each new casting announcement. There are two things in this trailer that I don't love. The first is Ewan McGregor's French accent (but a very reliable source told me that LumiÃ¨re's dialogue in the trailer is from an old take and was rerecorded for the actual film). The second is that the opening logo says "Disney" instead of "Walt Disney Pictures", but I guess that can't be helped. Other than that, everything looks spectacular. I can't wait to see this movie; it's going to be absolutely magical!

text: I'm super excited for this. Beauty & The Beast is one of my favourite Disney movies. I have LOVED the live action so far. I think for me, it's because they cut back on the songs.Â I grew up on Disney movies, these feel more on our level now as we've grown up. Maleficent was amazing, Jungle Book was okay(didn't like the cartoon much in the first place), Cinderella was great(didn't like that cartoon much but loved the movie). I really hope Disney keeps making their movies into live action. Would be really excited for The Little Mermaid, maybe an Ursula movie(like how they're doing Cruella). Maleficent really changed how you felt the villain, more movies could do the same.

text: Hm.  I'm not especially excited for this movie, but this is definitely a good trailer, at any rate.  And the movie will probably be okay, but I mean, I'm kind of biased because I'm that guy who, when he watches Beauty and the Beast, just spends a day watching it 3 or 4 times in one sitting, first normally, then with commentary, and finally the rough cut before they finalized all of the animation.  What I'm saying is, while I have a softer spot in my heart for Aladdin(the first movie I ever saw, ever), I really do feel like Beauty and the Beast is the best animated (non-Pixar) Disney movie.  This live-action remake is probably more for a newer audience than myself.  but yo if you reading this disney give us live action black cauldron for real

text: Narrator: "Once upon a time, in a faraway land, a young prince lived in a shining castle. Although he had everything his heart desired, the prince was spoiled, selfish, and unkind. But then, one winter's night, an old beggar-woman came to the castle, and offered him a single rose in return for shelter from the bitter cold. Repulsed by her haggard appearance, the prince sneered at the gift and turned the old woman away. But she warned him not to be deceived by appearances, for beauty is found within. And when he dismissed her again, the old woman's ugliness melted away, to reveal a beautiful Enchantress. The prince tried to apologize, but it was too late, for she had seen that there was no love in his heart. And as punishment, she transformed him into a hideous beast, and placed a powerful spell on the castle, and all who lived there. Ashamed of his monstrous form, the Beast concealed himself inside his castle, with a magic mirror as his only window to the outside world. The rose she had offered was truly an enchanted rose, which would bloom until his 21st year. If he could learn to love another, and earn her love in return, by the time the last petal fell, then the spell would be broken. If not, he would be doomed to remain a Beast for all time. As the years passed, he fell into despair, and lost all hope. For who could ever learn to love a beast?"
author: Rafferty Keegan-Sharief

text: I really hope Disney doesn't mess this one up like the other live  actions they've done recently . Beauty and The Beast is quite unique in  that it has a storyline that if adapted correctly has the potential of  being a very deep and meaningful movie. A film about self sacrifice and  the power of forgiveness is exactly what we need after the mess that was  2016. I also hope they put as much effort into the musical score as  they will the CGI because the piano solo's are particularly good and can  be made unforgettable to a whole new generation if scored correctly. I  think they have the right people cast, now we just gotta hope the  writers, producers and director are on point. My fingers are crossed.

text: Not sure how to feel about this. On the one hand, if you've never watched Disney's 'Beauty and the Beast' version, this is a *perfect* way to get into it. :D I can't imagine a better time to reintroduce this cherished classic to the younger generations.  On the other hand, if you've already seen and grew up with this movie, it's basically the same movie, except done with CGI and live actors. It's no different than getting the same car model, but with fancy wipers and new rims this time.  Are we going to get a live-action/CGI movie of the Lion King too? The Little Mermaid?   It's not that I'm not against revisiting old classics - far from it! o_o I enjoy remakes if they strike a nice balance between nostalgia and originality. It's why I enjoy seeing various renditions of Snow White; each film I've seen so far has their own take of that story. However, if Disney is recycling and upgrading old musical scores, same scenes, same narrative, then that takes away from the 'WOW' and originality factor of the original.   Everyone flipped their shit when the ballroom dance first appeared onscreen. We hadn't seen anything done like that before. Beauty and the Beast was one of the first Disney films to explore computer generated imagery.  With this new live-action adaption, I really hope the creative team can come up with something to WOW us; to show us something that hasn't been done before; to really push that CGI to its furthest limits so that THIS movie adaption can stand on its own and be remembered in future generations to come. :)

text: Unfortunately, this is a copy of a faulty fairy tale.  What would be more meaningful and honest would be the actual story.  Of those afflicted with hypertrichosis and the manner in which they were sought out, captured, and enslaved by monarchs.  It is not a fairy tale.  Nor is it a story for young children.  It is one more example of the extreme cruelty of humanity.  Yet, Disney continues to use a reformed evasion of the true horrors of history to profit.  To remake this lie for the purpose of profitability is disgusting.  To ignore the truth is a most grievous crime!Gonsalvus first came to the court of Henry II, King of France in 1547, and was sent from there to the court of Margaret of Parma, regent of the Netherlands. He married while there. Later he was moved into the court of Alexander Farnese, Duke of Parma. Four of his seven children were also afflicted with hypertrichosis universalis and painted.[2]  His family became an object of medical inquiry by Ulisse Aldrovandi  among others. Despite living and acting as a nobleman, Gonsalvus and his  hairy children were not considered fully human in the eyes of their  contemporaries. Gonsalvus eventually settled in Italy with his wife. The  last known record of him is from 1617, when he was listed among those  who had attended his grandson's christening. It is believed that  marriage with Petrus Gonsalvus and lady Catherine inspired the fairy  tale Beauty and the Beast.[3][4] He died in 1618 in Capodimonte.

text: Henagar Drive-In has refused to show B&tB because the LeFou character is gay. Here is their statement: { "When companies continually force their views on us we need to take a stand." }  Did they actually say that? They are dictating what their customers can and can not see, and not allowing them to choose for themselves, so essentially they are forcing *their* views on everyone else. Sounds like a double standard to me. How many other sins will they be boycotting at the Henagar Drive-In? I'd better not see anything higher than a 'G' rating being shown there! smh.
